turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Help me change the Skywire settings. Add five degrees to each satellite coordinate.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Gary, don't worry, we --

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Just do what I'm asking!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Okay, #2.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Longitude 48 degrees 06 minutes --

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Ready for number three?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Longitude 109 --

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Wait... He knows.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: 'Knows I'm altering the coordinates. Let's jump to #12.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Gary?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Just do it.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: All the companies know. The faculties tell 'em. At the target schools.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: In exchange for endowments. They should just drop the pretense and name the schools after 'em.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I think you should go.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I mean, it's your life.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I know you lost all his work. Maybe I could come down here and --

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You are naive. Look at your employment contract: you can't work anywhere else in this field for at least few years.  Not that I don't miss you.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Just thought his work should go on.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: He was on the verge of something, too. He was gonna show us the next day. He said "The answer's not in the box, it's in the band." Know what it means?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's only meaningful when you've got 40,000 lines of code to back it up.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Man, could he write code. Totally elegant. He had his own style.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Those really weird, short lines.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Your app kind of blew mine out of the water.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: We'll come up with the next big thing.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: ...You wanna work -- here?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Got out of my other commitment.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You guys'll be using Teddy's old space, is that okay?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Cool.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Could it be a glitch? Something the construction workers caused?

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: Unlikely. All 14 cameras are frozen. Do we call Randy and Phil? Tell 'em there may have been a break-in?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Not yet. 'Love to bust my ass cause I'm not in frigging Mensa.  I swear to God, it's that kid Milo, I told 'em so in the first place, but they didn't even wanna hear about it.  Let's run a printout on card entries.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: Every entry was authorized.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Keep looking.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: What're we looking for?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Any irregularity in the pattern.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: Delbert seems to enter #21 twice. Without leaving the first time.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Let's get him in here.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: Get the backslash, the colon, keys kids don't use but geeks do.  What would Milo want in here, anyway?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: They know. 'Just they don't trust me with it. So we'll get the evidence, first, ask questions later.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: You calling Phil and Randy?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: I'm calling Gary.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Come with me.

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: Where we going?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Now what are we doing? I don't get any of this shit!

turns.speaker: LEN
turns.text: I launched Skywire. Just pray the last set of coordinates Milo sent me connected us to Gary's satellite.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Lisa.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You know my name.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You know mine.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You're famous around here.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I'm getting a teacher's pet rep.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I wouldn't worry about it. You've gotta figure most people around here were their teachers' pets.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...Were you?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: We moved around so much I barely knew my teachers.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Me too! Were you an Army brat or something?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: ...Something like that. Yeah.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Didn't mean to pry. I just have this theory. Some of us who got to good at this? We were -- escaping something.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Did I say something?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: No, I know what you mean. I used to spend my life wishing people could be like computers. Least they make sense. Sometimes you think they've betrayed you. Like a person would. But then you see, no, you just missed a step. You can go back and make it all work.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What've you got there?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Graphical interfaces. For Skywire? I'm s'posed to coordinate with you.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Cool!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Yeah? I ran it for lots of platforms, ranging from the narrowest bandwidth to --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Did you wanna be alone?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No. Please.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: They just pushed up the schedule on Skywire apps. How fast are you going?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: "There is no second place." Plus every time I get jammed-up, Gary has an inspiration.  Is it like that with your counselor?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Mine's not the CEO. He barely remembers to take a shower.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Right, right. But does he ever just, like, hand you code?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Maybe once. I re-wrote it, anyway.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You're compulsive.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Mmm-more like -- I have a little trouble. Trusting people.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Why's that?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Long story. Not that interesting.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: So, when you were talking about wishing people were more like computers. Was that then? Or now?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Then and now.  But not right now.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: That's great. I -- didn't know.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: She saved my life.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I snuck into #21.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Why would you do a thing like --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You thought about it too. You've been suspicious for a while. But it's not happening in there. It's happening in the Day Care.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: The Day Care?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's easy to know who the smart geeks are, the schools tell 'em. They upload medical files, school records, pharmacy files. They'd be happy just to steal code forever. But when a program gets close to fruition. Like Teddy. He was almost there.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But why would they --?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You know. There is no second place. And what's the risk? The killings're undetectable, they're hand-tailored, they make "sense." I mean, they're in the information business. They have scenarios for all of us, too. In case we find out too much.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I know why you're so secretive. Why you won't let anybody near you.  I know what he did to you.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Is that my -- scenario?  Tell me.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They'd frame him.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: He's out of prison?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They're already watching you. If they had to, they'd give him this drug that mimics an alcoholic blackout. He'd wake up not even remembering his "act of revenge."

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: ...Milo?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I always felt if a -- boy I liked ever found out -- he'd run. He'd think I was unclean.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No, no. Never.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What about the FBI?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They've got this guy in the DOJ, maybe others. We tell the wrong person, it's over.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Who can we trust?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: There's always a logical answer -- you just have to define the question.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Do we post it on the Net?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: There're so many disinformation sites about Gary already. Where he has devil's horns or they crop him in with Saddam Hussein.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: The mainstream media. TV, or a newsmagazine.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Right. But Gary's tied-in to a lot of media conglomerates. Have to be careful who we pick.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: We could cross-reference a data base on media ownership. But not on our own computers. Not even at home.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Certainly not at my happy home.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He's buying up pretty much everything: cable companies, baby bells, picture libraries, museum rights, film archives... Getting ready for Skywire.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What about "60 Minutes."

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Yeah, they dig stuff like this.  "CBS News has partnered with Outpost Information Systems in a cable news network due to launch Fall of 2001."

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But still, you can't say CBS wouldn't love to break something like --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Say there's just one "mole" working there, like Barton at the DOJ. How do we know he's not the guy we've contacted? Or she? Or the guy she works for?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Time?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Time-Warner has a 40 per cent stake in Gary's set-top device. That also takes out CNN.  "GE joins Outpost in new venture," which means NBC is out. "Disney joins Outpost," ABC is out. "Outpost and Newscorp in new deal," Fox is out. Any of these places could have a mole. Or all of 'em.  It's like a a continuous loop. We can go to some alternative press place that 1,000 people read, get them and us killed. But anything big enough for this is a parent of or a subsidiary to something Gary's got a finger in!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: How close are you?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: He's got 12 satellites up. He's got dishes on top of 21. He's building this --  mega-network for Skywire. Let's use it.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: We can't just assume they're standing by to receive Skywire 12 months from launch. I'd have to write in an aglet.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's how on-line services push logos they wanna sell you. You don't ask for 'em, they just appear. 'Have to work on it somewhere besides my office or my house. And then the quality of the broadcast wouldn't exactly be digital, that's 12 months away.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But they'd still get the idea, right?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You'd have to design a graphic interface to make the data pop. Maybe some audio, too. To tie it all in to Gary. How long would that take you?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's a standard GUI. Once I've got a concept, it's maybe three day's work.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Gary knows I'm close on Skywire. We have to do this fast.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Before they kill somebody else, too.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Oh, man. I'd have to get into Gary's house. To get the satellite positions.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You mean -- break in?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I don't know --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And what if the broadcast dishes on top of 21 aren't hot yet? You said the place isn't finished.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Why were you so careless?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I thought the worst they would do is fire me. Who knew they took termination so literally?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Why were you snooping in my office?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh.  I liked you. I was checking you out.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: 'Think everybody in this place is here the same reason we are?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: 'Cause their apartments might be bugged?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I told Teddy about you.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What'd he say?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: "A beautiful geek? What're the chances?"

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I felt guilty. 'Cause I "owed so much" to Alice. But even then I was starting to wonder. Is it so great to be so consumed by this one thing that you let another person do your thinking for you? If you have a lucrative skill, it's all anybody wants from you. You grow older but you don't grow up. You turn into -- into --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Gary.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Great. I knocked off the aglet, as soon as I get a passable version of Skywire we're there.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: The dishes are juiced up, too.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Thank God.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Milo? Shrot suspects somebody broke into #21. I was in his office when he was reviewing the card readouts.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They know I broke in. Alice helped me.  Shrot's not one of them. He's blundering into this on his own.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: He doesn't know about the Day Care.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Hardly anybody does, that's the beauty part. No cameras, the DOJ doesn't bother with it, it's accessed by a tunnel they boast about. You know the best place to hide a leaf?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Yeah, that's old, in a tree.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Milo? What if Shrot notices somebody entered the Day Care at four A.M.? And tells them about it?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Same with the excerpts I'm choosing: they'll play against any of the images you described.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Perfect.  How am I gonna get away from the party long enough to --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You could always say you have to go the bathroom.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: That's lame, isn't it?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You'll come up with something.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Does he know you know?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He suspects I know something. I think he was sort of -- explaining himself to me, in case I do.  We have to go in tonight. I'm two hours from a Beta version.  But I've gotta go home for an hour.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Why?!

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: She called to apologize. I said I was pulling an all-nighter. She said then come home just to say Hi. Which I always do when we fight, it's suspicious if I don't.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Please don't go.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: At this point the worst thing I could do is anything out of the ordinary.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Meet me at the other location.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Tell me you're not calling on your car phone?!

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They know, I had no choice. Get out of the house now! Do you have a laptop?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's three years old, it --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Bring it to the other location.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But you said the other --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Maybe it's the satellite.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Let's try #2.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...He knows.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He's been altering the coordinates since we logged on. He's a step ahead. Let's jump to #12.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Latitude 47 degrees.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Wait a second. He knows I know.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...You got my E-mail?

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: And your phone messages. You wanna do what you do, it's not a crime.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Is that how Larry feels?

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: Uh. Not exactly.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Wanted to say goodbye to him...

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: Hey, we got seed money for the startup! A million-five!

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: We rented a loft in Sunnyvale.  You know what's the bad part? We can't talk about work anymore. We're competitors! The venture capitalists made us sign like 100 confidentiality forms.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Outpost made me sign 1,000. 'Guess we'll find out what else we have to talk about. Life stuff.

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: But these, like, White Supremacists trashed my office, last week.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: They're in the neighborhood. They usually hassle Vietnamese grocers.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Jesus, Teddy.

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: I'm cool. They didn't touch the machine. Or my disks. Probably didn't know what they were. So, you a Moonie yet?  Milo?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I met this girl.

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: What? Come on. Is it serious?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: Did you tell Alice?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No! I keep thinking it'll go away. But there's this -- connection. She's been hacking since she was little, she had to move around a lot. Plus I see her every day, we're working on the same program. She's -- beautiful.

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: A beautiful geek? I don't wanna sound paranoid, or like a pig, but what're the chances?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What d'you mean?

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: I dunno. I guess Larry's got me totally suspicious of that place.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: TEDDY
turns.text: Milo, geeks don't have two girlfriends. Most don't have one.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I didn't plan this.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: So -- how far are we from the campus?

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: Oh we're not going to the campus.

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: So how'd you like the house?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: His Snapples were in alphabetical order.

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: Well, he micro-managed the company till it got too big...  'Guess he needs to micro-manage something.

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: Every geek here's got a thing for Lisa. But that's about the biggest reaction she's had to anybody.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: She's a programmer?

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: Heavy graphical background, doing design-interface for Skywire apps.  You'll be working with her.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I've got a girlfriend, remember?

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: Right. That's rare around here. You know how nuns' re-married to Jesus? 'Posties are married to Outpost.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What're they building?

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: #21. Way behind schedule. It's top- secret, but everybody knows it's a digital broadcast space. They see the dishes on top, the fiber optics going in.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Gary's not into fiber optics. He's betting everything on the satellites.

turns.speaker: REDMOND
turns.text: You wanna survive in the software business, you cover your bets... I gotta say, this is the weirdest car anybody ever requested.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: We tried the big vaporware number, Gary, it's no-sale.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Can we buy into their IPO? Or is that a Justice Dept. problem?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: There is no public offering. The guy who wrote it joined some freakazoid cult in San Luis Obispo. 'Wrote this just to run their web site.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Maybe he'll get back to work.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Speaking of which...

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Did you download Corey? In San Jose?

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Damn. 'Have to go back over there.  Be so much easier if we could walk in the front door.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: You don't look anything like a three- year-old.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Not much. Glorified cherry bomb. Right by the civil defense sign? Some geek's idea of irony. I been saying we need a camera in this hall.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: There's nothing in this hall. Someone's pulling your chain, as usual.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Unless it's a diversion. Milo's in my office. He was tailgating, so I --

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: That kid's the great white hope.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: I could get it out of him.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: You're not listening.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Who're these guys?

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: We're too late. Take a look.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: Fellas, I'm gonna have to ask you to leave here now.

turns.speaker: SHROT
turns.text: Wait a second. I'm the one who found out he was mucking around in here in the first place.

turns.speaker: RANDY
turns.text: We're all grateful for that. Really. Go out the way you came in?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: You seem surprised to see me.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: I thought you'd quit while you were ahead.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: What, and watch all my earnings go...  Down the toilet?

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: What do you want, Mr... Cunningham, was it?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Call me Ritchie, Miss Fagina. May I call you Alotta...  Please?

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: You may.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Your boss, Number Two, I understand that cat's involved in big underground drills.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Virtucon's main interest is in cable television, but they do have a subterranean construction division, yes. How did you know?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I didn't, baby, you just told me.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: It's for the mining industry, Mr. Cunningham. We can talk about business later. But first, let me slip into something more comfortable.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Behave!

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I'd rather talk about Number Two.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Don't you like girls, Mr. Cunningham? Come in, and I'll show you everything you need to know.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: May I wash you?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Groovy.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: In Japan, men come first and women come second.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Or sometimes not at all.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Care for some saki?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Sak-i it to me!

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: How do you feel, Mr. Cunningham?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Mmmm... I feel extreme relaxation.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: 'Pardon me for being rude, It was not me, it was my food.  It just popped up to say hello, and now it's gone back down below.'

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: That's very clever. Do you know any other poems?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: 'Milk, milk, lemonade.  Round the corner fudge is made.  Stick your finger in the hole, And out comes a tootsie roll!'

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Thank you, that's beautiful. To your health.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: To my health.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Kiss me.

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Do you mind if I ask you a personal question?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Is it about my teeth?

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Damn. What exactly do you do at Virtucon?

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: I'll tell you all in due time, after we make love. But first, tell me another poem.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I think it was Wordsworth who penned this little gem: 'Press the button, pull the chain, out comes a chocolate choo-choo train.'

turns.speaker: ALOTTA
turns.text: Oh, you're very clever. Let's make love, you silly, hairy little man.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Austin Powers? Hi, I'm Andy Warhol.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Hey, how are you?

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: Hungry.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Here, have this can of Campbell's Tomato Soup.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: I'm going to paint this can of soup and become famous and not give you any credit for it.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: If you can become famous, everyone will have their fifteen minutes of fame, man.

turns.speaker: ANDY WARHOL
turns.text: "Fifteen minutes of fame?" I'm going to use that quote and not give you any credit for that, either.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Smashing!

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Hello, Austin. This is Basil Exposition, Chief of British Intelligence.  You're Austin Powers, International Man of Mystery, and you're with Agent Mrs. Kensington. The year is 1967, and you're talking on a picture phone.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: We know all that, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: I just wanted to be extremely clear so that everyone knows what's going on at any given time. We've just received word that Dr. Evil, the ultimate square, is planning to take over the world.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Dr. Evil? I thought I put him in jail for good.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: I'm afraid not. Earlier this week, Dr. Evil escaped from Zedel Edel Prison in Baaden Baaden and now he's planning a trap for you tonight at the Electric Psychedelic Pussycat Swinger's Club in Picadilly Circus here in swinging London.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Just where you'd never think to look for him. We'll be there.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Good luck, Austin.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Oh, and Austin...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you.  Let's go, baby!

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Where am I?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: You're in the Ministry of Defense. It's 1997. You've been cryogenically frozen for thirty years.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: The shouting is a temporary side- effect of the unfreezing process.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes, I'm having trouble controlling...  THE VOLUME OF MY VOICE!

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: You might also experience a slight fever, dry mouth, and flatulence at moments of extreme relaxation. Austin, this is Commander Gilmour, Strategic Command, and General Borschevsky, Russian Intelligence.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Russian Intelligence? Are you mad?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: A lot's happened since you were frozen, Austin. The cold war's over.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank God. Those capitalist dogs will finally pay for their crimes against the people, hey Comrades?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: We won, Austin.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Groovy. Smashing! Good on ya!  Nice tie. Yea capitalism!

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: When do I begin?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Immediately. You'll be working with Ms. Kensington.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: You mean Mrs. Kensington?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: No, Austin, Mrs. Kensington has long- since retired. Ms.  Kensington is her daughter.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Vanessa's one of our top agents.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: My God, Vanessa's got a smashing body. I bet she shags like a minx. How do I tell them that because of the unfreezing process, I have no inner monologue?  I hope I didn't say that out loud just now.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Yes, well...Agent Kensington will get you set up. She's very dedicated. Perhaps, a little too dedicated.  She's got a bit of a bug up her ass. Good luck, Austin, the world's depending on you.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Oh, and Austin...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Hello Austin. Hello Vanessa. This is Basil Exposition, from British Intelligence.  There's a company in Las Vegas called Virtucon that we think may be linked to Dr. Evil. Many of the Virtucon executives gamble at the hotel/casino where you'll be staying. That's the first place you should look.  Well, I'm off to the chat rooms.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Oh, and Austin...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Hello, Austin, this is Basil Exposition from British Intelligence. Thank you for confirming the link between Dr. Evil and Virtucon. Find out what part Virtucon plays in something called Project Vulcan. I'll need you and Vanessa to get on that immediately.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Right away, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Where is Vanessa, by the way?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: She's working on another lead right now.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Then you'll have to go it alone. Good luck.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you, Basil.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Oh, and Austin...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Let me remind you that because of the unfreezing process you might experience flatulence at moments of extreme relaxation.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Oh, yes. Thank you.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: There's one more thing, Austin.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Hello, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Austin, Vanessa, let me bring you up to speed. Dr. Evil has high- jacked a nuclear warhead from Kreplachistan and is holding the world ransom for one-hundred billion dollars. If the world doesn't pay up in four days, he's threatening to destroy the world.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thank you, Exposition. Only two things, scare me, and one is nuclear war.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: What's the other?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: What's the other thing you're scared of?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Carnies.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Circus folk.  Nomads, you know. They smell like cabbage.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Indeed... If we could get back to the business at hand. It's one thing to have a warhead, it's quite another thing to have the missiles to launch it.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Maybe these photographs are the last piece of that puzzle.  I've uncovered the details on Project Vulcan. It's a new subterranean warhead delivery system.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Good God, and underground missile. We've long feared such a development.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: My God, Austin, what have you done?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: That's not your mother, that's a man!

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I'm sorry, Basil, I thought she was a man.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Damn it, man! You're talking about my mother!

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: You must admit, she is rather mannish. No offense, but if that's a woman, it looks like she's been beaten with an ugly stick.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: All right, Austin, I think you should go.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I think if everyone were honest, they'd confess that the lady looks exactly like a man in drag.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: I'm leaving!  Oh, and Austin?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes, Basil?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Well, Austin, you've stopped Dr. Evil from destroying the world with his subterranean nuclear probe, and somehow you and Agent Kensington managed to escape unscathed from his evil lair.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I'd say that about sums it up, Exposition.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Not quite, actually. Vanessa, I have something for you.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Congratulations, Field Agent Kensington!

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Austin, I have something for you as well.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Here's the number of my dentist, he's first rate. Ring him up, he'll look after you.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Thanks, Basil. Maybe the Nineties aren't so bad after all.

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: But, wait, I-- you got me again. Oh, and Austin--

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Yes Basil?

turns.speaker: BASIL EXPOSITION
turns.text: Be careful!

turns.speaker: MICK JAGGER
turns.text: Hey Austin Powers, it's me, Mick Jagger.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Hey, Mick!

turns.speaker: MICK JAGGER
turns.text: Are you more satisfied now sexually, Austin?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Well, you can't always get what you want.

turns.speaker: MICK JAGGER
turns.text: "You can't always get what you want!" That's a great title for a song! I'm gonna write that, and it'll be a big hit.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Good on ya, man.

turns.speaker: MICK JAGGER
turns.text: Groovy!

turns.speaker: DESTRUCTACON
turns.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Powers, I'm the Destructacon 5000. I'm programmed to prevent you from progressing beyond this point. You might as well surrender. Resistance is futile. Your odds of survival are 23,763,273 to...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Well, Destructacon 5000, you have quite a head on your shoulders, I dare to coin.

turns.speaker: DESTRUCTACON
turns.text: Yes, I am programmed to answer any question.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Really? Let me ask you this. What is love?

turns.speaker: DESTRUCTACON
turns.text: That does not compute.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Why not? It's a question.

turns.speaker: DESTRUCTACON
turns.text: Love is... love is... love is...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: What's wrong with your hand?

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Don't try to suck up to me! It's a little late for that. I'm a freak! Look at it, it's been rendered useless.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I'm sorry, baby, I'm just not grocking your head space.

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Oh forget it. As a fellow player on the international stage, Mr.  Powers, I'm sure you'll enjoy watching the curtain fall on the third and final act.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Dr. Evil, do you really expect them to pay?

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: No, Mr. Powers, I expect them to die. Even after they pay me the money, I'm still going to melt all the cities of the world with hot magma.  All right, guard, begin the unnecessarily Slow-Moving Dipping Mechanism.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I've got you, Dr. Evil!

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Well done, Mr. Powers. We're not so different, you and I. It's true, you're British, and I'm Belgian. You have a full head of hair, mine is slightly receding. You're thin, I'm about forty pounds overweight. OK, we are different, I'm not making a very good point. However, isn't it ironic, Mr. Powers, that the very things you stand for-- swinging, free love, parties, distrust of authority- are all now, in the Nineties, considered to be... evil? Maybe we have more in common than you care to admit.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: No, man, what we swingers were rebelling against were uptight squares like you, whose bag was money and world domination. We were innocent, man. If we'd known the consequences of our sexual liberation, we would have done things differently, but the spirit would have remained the same.  It's freedom, man.

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Your freedom has cause more pain and suffering in the world than any plan I ever dreamed of. Face it, freedom failed.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: That's why right now is a very groovy time, man. We still have freedom, but we also have responsibility.

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Really, there's nothing more pathetic than an aging hipster.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: It seems the tables have turned again, Dr. Evil.

turns.speaker: DR. EVIL
turns.text: Not really. Kill the little bastard. See what I care.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Man, you are one chilly square!

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: Mr. Powers, my job is to acclimate you to the Nineties. You know, a lot's changed since 1967.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Well, as long as people are still having promiscuous sex with many anonymous partners without protection, while at the same time experimenting with mind-expanding drugs in a consequence-free environment, I'll be sound as a pound.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: My mother's told me all about you.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: If it's a lie, goddamn her. It it's the truth, goddamn me.  God, I hope that's witty. How's your mum?

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: My mother's doing quite well, thank you very much.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: OK, OK, man, don't get heavy, I'll sign. Just to get things moving, baby.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: Listen, Mr. Powers, I look forward to working with you, but do me a favor and stop calling me baby. You can address me as Agent Kensington. We have to leave immediately. We've preserved your private jet just as you left it. It's waiting at Heathrow Airport.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: My jumbo jet? Smashing baby.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Pretty groovy Jumbo Jet, eh? How does a hot chick like you end up working at the Ministry of Defense?

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: I went to Oxford and excelled in several subjects, but I ended up specializing in foreign languages. I wanted to travel -- see the world. In my last year I was accepted into the M.O.D. in the Cultural Studies sector. I thought I was off on an exciting career, but my job was to read everything printed in every country. It's very boring. My whole day is spent reading wedding announcements in Farsi. If I do well with this case, I finally get promoted to field operative...

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: That's fascinating, Vanessa. Listen, why don't we go into the back and shag?

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: I've been frozen for thirty years, man, I want to see if my bits and pieces are still working.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: My wedding tackle.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: I'm sorry?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: My meat and two veg.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: Mr. Powers, please. I know that you must be a little confused, but we have a very serious situation at hand. I would appreciate it if you'd concentrate on our mission and give your libido a rest.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: Have you ever made love to a Chigro?

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: A Chigro?

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: You know, a Chigro... part Chinese, part Negro...  Chigro.

turns.speaker: VANESSA
turns.text: We don't use the term 'Negro' anymore. It's considered offensive.

turns.speaker: AUSTIN
turns.text: That's right. You're supposed to say 'colored' now, right?  Here's the stewardesses! Bring on the sexy stews!
